Review_body: i bought this movie while i was passing through a "hitchcockian" phase.it all started by buying vertigo after reading all the good reviews,and i really liked it.then my second pick was psycho which i already saw on TV,but really watching it on DVD was different,i loved it.then i bought the birds,supposedly another masterpiece...i was slightly disappointed,the characters are underdeveloped,the storyline is one-dimensional,the whole concept of the movie is more like a documentary than a real movie(especially a Hitchcock movie). ...........but,the birds really is a shocking and strange film and it has it's share of hitchcockian black humor.i guess if u deal with the fact that this movie has no musical score,no plot,no character development and no real human emotion,then...u may love it.but if u want real Hitchcock,try "vertigo","psycho","rear window" and the less notorious but perfect "notorious".

Review title: The Birds vs The birds as written by author.
Review_body: Nothing like the book. Yet Hitchcock was suppose to be a fan.The book does not need altering for dramatic effect, true is is written by an English Lady and set in England, but it could be set in the USA as still keep true.Both end with no conclusion, but in the book it is a wide spread attack, possibly the whole world, making the danger far greater than the film, where most attacks are only at that bay. Of course there is no glamorous blonde in the book, but instead centers around a married man trying to keep his wife and children safe. The film is set in summer, where as the book in winter, Hitchcock also added an attractive school teacher and townsfolk, all not in the book.So you lose the isolation of the farm where the family live. The film is fine if you don't know the story, and I admit I quite enjoyed it, but please don't see it as a work by Daphne Du Maurier as it is not her story.

So much has been written about this movie, its hard to know what angle to approach it.The story concerns an attractive, blonde socialite/High society woman who visits a pet shop and bumps into a dashing Dan dare type Lawyer with a biting wit and acid tongue. They flirt and tease and she decides to buy a pair of lovebirds for his baby sister. She makes a surprise visit to his apartment to deliver the birds, finds out that he is on vacation and decides to visit him in Bodega Bay, lovebirds in toe.Calm before the storm.From the moment Melanie arrives in Bodega Bay right up until the inscrutable ending, the landscape is brutalized by a succession of random bird attacks.Volumes have been written on the possible causes.Are the attacks freudian in their revenge? Do they come at times of sexual tension or indifference between the star players? Are the towns folk being divinely punished for their mistreatment of these feathered friends. "Back in your gilded cage Melanie Daniels", says Mitch, "Two southern fried chickens", an order from the waitress, the birds pov shot above the town looking down on the devastation. These moments could all be nature's revenge, after all there are many references to caging and eating birds in the film.Have we been too complacent about life for too long and have we taken these birds for granted? Is it man's wake up call to treat nature with more respect? Is this all a manifestation of Mitch's sexual frustration and annoyance at his clinging mother who can't let go? Who knows but too wallow and psychoanalyse in this is largely missing the point. The true strength of this picture is in its visual power and assembly of shots. Hitchcock employs so much trickery and gimmickry that you are left feeling that you have just watched a lesson in montage and composition. Static shots are interrupted by movement and the process is repeated. Its like watching an eerie photograph punctuated by forward zooms and then back to the freeze frame. Many angles and points of view are shown. This not only disorientates the viewer but makes for great action sequences and startling imagery.The technical stunt works brilliantly.8 out of 10.

Of course Alfred Hitchcock's The Birds is a classic and a great movie for many reasons. The camera angles, panning and tracking, the suspenseful plot, the emotion in the story-line and actors, and of course the great actors and actresses Hitchcock used.But there always seems to be a very interesting underlying "symbolic message in the bottle" in Hitchcock's plot and sometimes it is not easy to decipher. Of all the reviews here about The Birds, the underlying message has escaped the other writers. Not sure why. Might be that people don't read many actual paper books anymore and spend long hours online where everything is "told to them". Maybe its because films are not really studied or analyzed anymore as much as they are consumed in a "entertain me now" kind of way.Anyway...the name of the movie itself should be a great hint of the underlying symbolic ideas. "The Birds" and thus the birds and the bees. The Birds and the Bees refer to the old ideology of the natural order of things which were changing at the time this movie was made. This idea of natural order encompassed the idea that only "men and women" were allowed to be in love, married and making love and that only men were supposed to be the pursuer in this natural order of human love.Hitchcock's plot opens in San Francisco, which at the time was just becoming known as a gay friendly city and was opening the doors for the gay liberation movement. This gay embrace was very shocking to conservative USA. This shock value was not lost on Hitchcock. Northern California was also the first to embrace women's equality and liberation. The first major impact of women's liberation was the sometimes reversal of pursuer roles and women becoming assertive in their pursuit of men if they so choose. Hitchcock utilized both of these ground breaking social changes in this movie, filmed in and near San Francisco, the center of both the gay liberation movement and the women's liberation movement.There were actually two symbolic messages that were carried together to Bodega Bay and none were in a bottle. One was in a cage and draws great symbolism captured in other famous stories such a La Cage aux Folles and the other broke the cage of women's conservative norms which eventually sweep the US and allowed women to finally spread their wings and fly. The first message was the love birds bringing their unnatural love to the quiet little village of Bodega Bay. Even to expert ornithologist, determining the love bird's sex is very difficult. So it could often happen that two love birds paired and affectionate could both be male or both female living life together monogamously. Here I believe that Hitchcock insinuated the Love Birds were of the same sex. This little message carried the notion of two gay partners coming into a small town and disrupting the existing conservative values. As the love birds were brought into Bodega Bay, their arrival rocked the natural order of things and the existing birds of the community rebelled, first attacking Melanie Daniels who brought them there in an open boat coming slowing across the central bay for all the local birds to see. They then eventually attacked the home which they resided and humans who were harboring them. This story could be easily paralleled with the La Cage story, abet much more suspenseful and horrific, of a gay couple coming into a small town and moving into a home and having the conservative townsfolk rebel. And rebel they did in the most horrific way imaginable. This rebellion was where Hitchcock came into his element and utilized his famous horror and suspense.And just as the love birds came into Bodega Bay and changed the natural order of things, so did their carrier in Melanie Daniels. Melanie broke all the normal rules and customs of the East Coast conservative male/female dynamic when she immediately began to seek, prey and chase her suitor Mitch Brenner. Racing her high performance sports car around the narrow curves of the Pacific Coast Highway, renting and manning a boat by herself to find his home, entering his property without permission or invitation, leaving a love letter on his desk and spying her prey from the bay on her skiff. All of these actions in the course of a few minutes broke the natural order of Victorian women's protocol wide open forever. She was a hungry tiger and very much upset the natural order of things which was most evident in Mitch's mother and the layers of emotional depth that involve a man and his conservative mother as the natural order is challenged or broken. Once the attacks began Melanie quickly took back her already antiquated role as a damsel in distress, which Hitchcock may have needed to enhance his dramatic suspense. But even in her damsel role, Hitchcock allowed Melanie much bravery and an equal level of courage to her co-star Mitch Brenner in the face of a brutal bird rebellion. Here Mitch's mother began to over come the shock of Melanie's aggressiveness and see the brave woman in a more human and accepting way. I think suspense and dramatic distress can be a wonderful instrument in which to allow the viewing of a character in a new and sympathetic light. Hitchcock clearly wanted to show the disruption in our presupposed notion of the natural order of the birds and the bees and also to show the effect of this disruption upon conservative small town societal values again a la Cage aux Folles. Yes, Hitchcock's symbolic message in a bottle. Yet another added dimension to an already brilliant film. Look for more of Hitchcock's underlying symbolic messages in his other great films Vertigo, Psych and North by Northwest.

The Birds failed to make it on the American Film Institute's list of one hundred greatest American movies, but nonetheless, it has still been influential. A true horror movie, The Birds inspired such films as Jaws, and is unique among Hitchcock films because, unlike others, which rely on psychological horror, The Birds is graphic, violent and terrifying. The plot follows a young woman (Tippi Hedron) as she journeys to a tiny village in northern California called Bodega Bay. It seems like an average small town until a bizarre event happens. Formerly peaceable birds suddenly begin attacking people without provocation. The first attack is nothing more than a knick from a seagull but larger swarms of birds begin to strike to kill and nobody can figure out the cause of such violence. The Birds makes use of some innovative filming techniques to capture the vicious scenes but Hitchcock was not above putting his actors in danger in order to get a shot. Most notably, the final attack scene was all real and live birds were used. The Birds is a good film but not necessarily a great one. It is a movie that seems to focus on the horror and intensity of the attacks rather than the logic behind them. Thus, the plot suffers and is not as strong as the story lines of previous Hitchcock films (although the plots of most Hitchcock movies seem to fall apart if over analyzed anyway.) The film also seemed to lack the star power of Hitchcock's previous movies. In its most primitive development, Hitchcock had wanted The Birds to star Cary Grant and Grace Kelly but the former was aging and the latter had married Prince Rainier of Monaco and had retired from acting. So, Hitchcock ended up with Rod Taylor and a rookie Tippi Hedron.

Review title: Don't bother if you value your sanity
Review_body: Alfred Hitchcock: depending on you, you will either love him or hate him with all your guts. If you like barf-causing horror and suspense to render your limbs into jelly, as well as a un-foreseeable twist, then this is your movie. It is appreciatable, no matter what. But if you are a person who appreciates movies that make you roar with laughter and recall it the next night with a smile, you will HATE this movie. It will render you to a trembling mass of nerves, and leave you fuming with outrage at the end. If you appreciate suspense, mystery, twists and a movie that will keep your eyes glued to the screen, you could not find a movie to beat The Birds. Otherwise, leave it well alone.
No plot, bad acting... don't bother wasting your time.

Review title: Cheesy, definitely not Hitchcock's finest,, but I love it anyway
Review_body: One of the reasons I like this film is because it takes place in my backyard, so to speak. I happen to live in the area where it was filmed and that's one of the reasons I enjoy watching it. Having said that, and being a Hitchcock fan, I definitely don't think this was anywhere up to his standards.I don't expect there to be a reason given for the bird attacks. That's a mystery and will remain one. What I can't get behind are some of the incredibly cheesy situations and silly dialogue. The conversation between Melanie and Annie for instance, after Melanie returns from having dinner with Mitch and his family. Annie goes into this whole explanation of Lydia's character and why she behaves the way she does. Yet, she says, Lydia is not a jealous, possessive mother????? When she relates her own experiences with Mitch and Lydia, Melanie makes the comment 'that adds up to a jealous possessive mother', or something along those lines. 'No', says Annie, she's not afraid of losing Mitch, she's just afraid of being abandoned'. Did I miss something here? I can't believe that Hitchcock allowed such senseless, pointless dialogue between his characters.Later Annie is found dead in front of her house, yet she manages to push Cathy inside, and Cathy doesn't have a scratch on her. Okay, maybe there is a way this could have happened but it does stretch the imagination a bit. Speaking of Cathy, I found the kid to be irritating beyond words. Fortunately for her, Veronica Cartwright's acting has greatly improved in the intervening years but she sure couldn't act in this film.Nevertheless, I find this film to be enjoyable and I watch it time and again. Despite the cheesiness and frequently contrived situations and the less than stellar characters, I think it's very entertaining. I just find it hard to believe it's a Hitchcock film.

Before I say anything else, I'll warn everybody that I may or may not put a spoiler in here; I never plan in advance on these.I thought that the movie lacked plot. Birds attack people. Birds attack people. Oh, by the way, people get attacked by birds! However, Hitchcock excelled at achieving an effect by that point in his career. The scenes are visually harrowing... I think Hitchcock built this film around the idea that the characters find themselves in an incomprehensible peril. After all, why do birds attack people? Why do people get attacked by birds? We find no motive; we don't understand. Besides the eye-gouging and attacks on children, the randomness of the attacks is the true horror.

One of Hitchcock's most popular movies, "The Birds" proves his reputation as "The Master of Suspense." There are many suspenseful and scary moments. You see the gas pooling around the vehicle as the idiot lights his cigarette at the pump. You see the birds gathering menacingly to...do what? Hitchcock's timing is perfect as the scene resolves as you knew it would.My favorite character is the ornithologist (amateur, I presume) lady at the gas station. She is so sure that birds would never behave in the manner described that you are almost eager for them to prove her wrong!I have seen the movie several times and enjoyed it very much. But it doesn't make my list of top Hitchcock films because it is more predictable than many others. And I found the ending dissatisfying.Want great characters and plot development? See "Vertigo" or "Rear Window."Plot twists? "The Man Who Knew Too Much" or "Psycho."Want a big surprise at the end? Try "North by Northwest."A superb adaptation of a Daphne duMaurier story? "Rebecca."Great acting? Any of the above, or "Strangers on a Train."An entertaining evening watching a relatively easy-to-follow plot by one of the greatest directors ever, while munching on your popcorn? Now you can see "The Birds."

Review title: A wonderful movie from the master of suspense!
Review_body: First off, Tippi Hedren was great for the part. This movie just shows that you don't need to have ANY music in a movie just to make it scary. It's great how Hitchcock slowly builds up the suspense, as he does in all his movies. The scary thing about this movie is that when you see it, it is not only scary to see these innocent people being attacked by the birds, but it's also sort of psychologically scary because Hitchcock almost forces you to believe that this could really happen at any time when we least expect it. In my opinion, the only REALLY scary scene is when Melanie goes upstairs and is attacked by the birds and is basically trapped, what makes that scene so scary was that the it shows the birds coming right at the camera and also that they show so many times the birds biting her hand in the same place, you feel likes it's almost happening to you. An excellent film but you might not want to see it if you are already a little afraid of birds.

Imagine Hitchcock trying to sell this idea to the film studios: the lives of a mundane country family are shattered when vicious rooks attack. Why? No particular reason. And what then? They fly away. and then? They come back again and attack. And then go and then . .. It seems like an impossible plot to pull off, but Hitchcock does it, slowly building up the tension which spasmodically swells and subsides. Younger viewers may get irritated with the slow stealth of the opening scenes and may want to thrash the T.V. when the film comes to its beautifully droll conclusion, but form once those birds start attacking, every viewer is riveted. It was fine Hitchcockian innovation that took this very slim, cock-a-mamy story and turned in to a tense thriller. But the greatest innovation is the film score - there isn't any. No director is more closely identified with the music of their films, but in Birds, Hitchcock created a horror that is uniquely  quiet. The great man appreciated something that so few others do - the atmospheric potency of silence, and how, in different settings, silences can differ in character. Yet so many who watch the film seem to forget that the music isn't there. That's the film's greatest attribute.

Review title: Whilst Psycho has been ripped off, parodied, copied and shudder Remade, there has never been another film like the Birds.
Review_body: I first saw this film when I was a cynical teenager, adamant that nothing could scare me, and it didn't- I point blank refused to let it happen.  Not the Exorcist, not Freddy or Jason and not the Birds could shake this tough-girl up. So now I am a bit older and wiser and I also know a lot more about film. And I watched the Birds again for a different look at it. It is SO cleverly done. As an earlier reviewer said, Hitch plays the audience like a finely tuned instrument and the effects can be stronger than you would realise especially for a 1963 film being watched in the 21st Century! (A lot of younger people seem to believe that old films are at best cute and at worse, old fashioned and irrelevant- oh if only they knew, they were so much worse than anything that is considered "Shocking" today) EXAMPLE: I am not scared of spiders but they bring out an almost primeval instinct in me, My hands sweat, I get cold shivers and goose bumps all over but at the same time my rational brain tells me it's ok and I pick up incy-wincy and chuck him out of the window- no problem. But after  I watched the Birds, it happened again. Some scenes gave me the shivers so bad that I thought I was going to flip out and hide in a cave somewhere and by bed time I was pumped so full of adrenaline that I couldn't get to sleep. It's Hitch you see, not only does he know film, he knows YOU as well and how to get to you.  I will try to keep it brief as to what makes this film so special. Firstly, he lands heavy portents on the characters.  The early scenes all end with a bird acting strange, in a variety of ways. Secondly, silence is sometimes golden.  The indoor attack sequences are unique in the reaction of the victims, I will say no more as it so effective and scary.  But at the same time it is the sort of thing I have nightmares about a remake putting in a ditzy female screaming or something, (please leave this film alone!) Thirdly- The sounds of the birds!  Enough said- I got that shiver again... Fourthly-Hitch tricks.  You KNOW she has a load of crows behind her, but then it turns out you had no idea at all.  He likes to lure the audience into a false sense of security "Don't worry chaps, I'll show you what's happening, just don't tell the actors" but when revelation occurs, you realise you've been had just as much as those on screen. Fively (?:-) there are some scenes which are truly horrific.  It's as simple as that.  It's a horror film. There are 6-10 points, I could go on all day but this is probably long enough.

In my English class we had to read "The Birds". After we read it, we watched the movie. Boy, was it different.First of all, it was nothing like the story, which I liked. The story was boring, but the movie was entertaining, to say the least.Second, you could definitely tell it was made in the 1960s. Unlike The Exorcist, the special effects were...laughably bad. But I understand they didn't have much technology then, so it's OK. The "disturbing" sound the birds made sounded more like angry cat meows than birds. It made me laugh every time. The green screen effect was just ridiculous. Plus the blood you could tell wasn't real, especially when we see Annie's dead, bloody face. Also, the "guy" with his eyes pecked out looks like a wooden figure. It probably was. Ha! 3rd, it was VERY cheesy. The romance was kinda uncalled for, and the acting was not that great.4th...as cheesy and ill-made as it seems, the movie is actually quite intriguing. It was very entertaining and gave me a good laugh. If you aren't afraid basically everything, you will get a good laugh out of it, and will probably like this movie. If you are afraid of everything, you're sure to get a scare from the gore, because, honestly, that's really all the "scare" the movie has.

Review title: Were phones really ever THAT big??
Review_body: I have an unwritten list of movies I've always wanted to see, just not bad enough to put any effort into watching. They'll usually pop up on television some night when I've got nothing better to do and I'll finally sit and watch. Sometimes this turns out well, like FIGHT CLUB, when I kick myself for not seeing the movie sooner. And sometimes it doesn't work out well at all for anyone involved.Turner Classic Movies was doing a Hitchcock thing yesterday, and I'm the sort of person for whom Hitchcock films can go either way. I love PSYCHO, I had no strong feelings either way on REAR WINDOW, and I honestly don't even remember 99% if NORTH BY NORTHWEST. Anyway, I'd never seen THE BIRDS, so I sat down and watched it last night.THE BIRDS has officially joined THE VILLAGE and WEST SIDE STORY as one of the most monumentally STUPID movies I've ever had the 'joy' of sitting the entire way through.Film blasphemy? Maybe. But what's Hitchcock gonna do about it? Come back from the dead to give me a slight backhand slap in the face? Maybe. I'll keep you posted.Anyway, I am of the opinion that there is a fine line between building suspense and boring the living crap out of me. Sometimes a movie can be boring but still entertain with cinematography, like BROKEBACK MOUNTAIN. I waited that entire movie for some sort of story or plot line that never happened, but at least it was pretty to look at.I spent so much of THE BIRDS waiting for something to actually happen that when it did, and by 'it' I'm referring to the guy standing in the puddle of gas who dropped his match and burst into flames, I honestly laughed out loud. It's just, 85% of this movie was just filler drudge I didn't need to see. Like people driving, parking, getting out of the car and walking to the next scene. Was there an editor shortage in 1963? That's not suspense, that's tedium.And you know, I'm fine with the fact that there's never an explanation offered for why the birds go nuts, that was okay. What I can't buy is how dang dumb every single character had to be about it. Hey look, a flock of birds is going to attack us. What should we do? Oh, I know, let's go outside and run around. Come on. I mean, come on. They're BIRDS. Just swat 'em down and step on 'em. They've got hollow bones and weigh less than a pound.And when the main character thinks she hears birds in the house, after everything that's just happened, and goes off on her own to investigate, and then finds a room that sounds like there's birds in it, so she manages to shut herself inside and then get attacked by birds... Frankly, she deserved to die. Though I really don't buy that you can be pecked to death instantly by birds.And how do we make our harrowing escape? Uh, the birds that just tried pretty darn hard to kill everyone are gonna just sit and watch while the movie's hero spends twenty minutes pulling the car up and walking everyone out the front door in slow motion, and then we'll just drive away. The end.Wait, what? I will say one thing for THE BIRDS, it has the absolutely most GIGANTIC telephones I've ever seen on film. And they paid for the phones, so darn it, they were gonna use 'em. This movie would've been shortened by 35-40 minutes if you eliminated the pointless phone conversations. It would've been over an hour shorter if touch-tone phones had replaced rotary dials by then.So anyway, yeah, THE BIRDS. Incredibly retarded movie.

I just COMMENT on what happens , WITHOUT ACTUALLY DESCRIBING IT. Safe if you want to see what "TYPE" of ending the movie has.The movie's ending is very important to me for judging it. It should give a meaning to the rest of it. Unfortunately, in "The Birds" there is no such ending. That makes the story unsatisfying as a plot, no matter how rich and climactic it is. Sometimes the end leaves you wonder about several explanations or outcomes of the story. Some other times you expect something but you get something even better. In this movie the ending just leaves you wondering "Why did I spend the last couple of hours watching this, waiting for something to happen?". If you like movie endings, you will be disappointed. Guaranteed.

While brilliantly staged and photographed, Hitchcock tortures the viewer from beginning to end with incongruous dialog, false tension, prolonged anxiety, and then at the long delayed finale, everybody goes into SLOW MOTION to reach the ultimate non-conclusion.

Review title: The Birds - The Community vs the Outsider
Review_body:
I think this movie is about the problems of outsiders in being accepted in a small self-contained community. The community is fine until Melanie shows up with the lovebirds. Nothing untoward happens until Rod Taylor jumps into the car to go after Melanie, thus effectively indicating his acceptance of Melanie into his world and into town life. Then comes the first attack.
Note the resemblance in hairstyles when Melanie meets Rod Taylor's mother. He is obviously searching for the love he did not find in his mother. As the birds do not accept the presence of Melanie and the lovebirds in town, so the mother will not accept a new woman in her son's life. She wants someone in her own life badly and realizes too late the barricades she has put up. Not even her own son has been allowed to enterThe birds single out for attack the sister, who befriends Melanie, and the schoolteacher, who takes her into her house. When the schoolteacher arrived in town, she was rejected by Rod Taylor, thus not incurring the enmity of the birds. Also note the striking moment when the woman at the restaurant hurls abuse at Melanie. "It's your fault! Nothing happened here until you came!" The community always seeks to ostracize and drive away the newcomer. The opera "Peter Grimes" tackles the same theme. The birds allow the family to leave as they have won. Melanie and the lovebirds drive off to San Francisco. The town can return to normal daily life. Anyway, that's my take on this Hitchcock opus.

The birds is simply one of Hitchcock's best films. It's not only his final masterpiece, but also the best film ever made about how we treat nature and how nature can strike back violently. Yet the best thing about THE BIRDS is how the film never takes itself too seriously, something not surprising given Hitchcock's peculiar sense of humor. And once again the undisputed master of suspense creates memorable scenes including the birds attack at the Bodega Bay gas station and one particular shot at the end of the movie involving a door that i will not spoil. Something so simple and yet so striking. And please, do yourself a favor and watch the film's unique trailer. A hands down classic!!!!!!!

If the lovebirds symbolise Melanies love, the other birds symbolise the mother's fear of abandomnet for me.
As the fear grows, thr attacks become mkre severe. But when Cathy brings the lovebirds in and Melanise shows the mother, she too needs her, the atracks cease.

Review title: Still has a big impact after all these years.
Review_body: The plot is simple but effective, it works because of the great detail Hitchcock employed, mainly the character development and the realistic location shots, you really believe in this place and the people, it is all too real! Another Hitchcock masterpiece.

Review title: You should watch this movie whether you think it's a great thriller or not.
Review_body: Tippi arrives in Bodega Bay in a fur and an expensive sports car with only a nightie in a paper bag for luggage. She spends the rest of the film in the same outfit for what must be more than a few days. That's just the tip of the iceberg folks for probability. Fine acting by some classical greats. Suzanne Pleshette and Jessica Tandy are so young you won't recognize them. And Charles McGraw in a very small role. Curiously, all the small roles in this Northern California coastal town have New England accents. This film is great if you believe that humans are the baddies and the cause of all the ecological disasters and that someday birds of all different kinds of feather will unite and wreak revenge on humankind. If you don't feel this way you may still really enjoy it for a lot of giggles. Did you ever see birds peck their way through a solid wood door? Well get ready. I hope this doesn't disqualify my review for spoiler or spiteful remarks. You may truly enjoy it as a classic Hitch thriller. Or, if you are like me, you may say to you self, "What was he thinking?"... and enjoy it giggling yourself silly.

I have nothing but admiration for this movie. While not afraid of it like I was when I first saw it when I was twelve, back then I saw the movie as somewhat prophetic, a "could be scenario' of the future. Maybe a reaction to the time of my life I was about to enter in to. Nature turning on its cruel masters scenario!! I even thought, with that teenage sense of smug superiority, that we deserved it!!I, of course think differently about it now. Hitchcock is such a master at portraying the futility of human relationships in light of such actions of finality. Mundane everyday things that we think are so important that are swallowed up by some acts of desperateness, ruthlessness or anything else we really have no control over. What does it take to shake us out of our complacency? In this movie, the signs are evident throughout, yet, it is almost too late and the end leaves you thinking, "Are we still too late? I always wonder, whenever I watch this movie, how we would react? Would we kill all the birds we could, not taking any mind as to the huge environmental disaster that such an action would bring about. Hopefully we would not, but the old nature dies hard when survival is at stake.So in my mind, The Birds is a a modern day morality play. It still has the power to move and still speaks to us. In any disaster, we will react. My question is and always will be, "How?"

it makes you think about mother nature taken back what is her.it was a well direct movie. and the director had a very good  cast to work with in the movie.i also like the setting where they made the movie. i like to know how they got the bird to attack the actor like they did?...jeff

I didn't see the Birds until it made it to TV some years later but at the time the children fleeing the schoolhouse left me physically shaking in horror.  Years later I had the opportunity to spend the night at the schoolhouse which was and still is one of my best memories to date. Hitch's plodding drama may seem slow by todays standards but I feel that is one of the very reasons the attacks are so delightful! You get caught up in this slow moving story and whamo the birds attack out of nowhere.  One wonders why after all these years no one has ever been able to recreate such a great film.  It's easy to imagine in these turbulent times that evil can come at any moment from the very things we take for granted and do not normally fear.  I am sure that is what drew Sir Alfred to this material in the first place.  Pass the popcorn!

Review title: This annoying blonde chick chases an arrogant lawyer to his house in Northern California and winds up being pecked by lots of birds.
Review_body: Okay, okay, I'm not blown away by Hitchcock (except Rear Window which is wonderful and I like even more than Psycho), but he definitely was a brilliant innovator. His obsession with his blonde leads gives me the creeps, however.I just saw "The Birds" for the first time since I was a child and I have to say, I remembered some of the key scenes from childhood, so that's significant, I guess. And I continued watching it so it did keep my interest.But I just don't understand why everyone is making such a fuss over this film NOW. I watched it WITH my cockatiel and we both thought it was pretty stupid. Tippi Hedron is an even WORSE actress than her daughter and that's saying a lot. She is SO annoying, dislike-able, rude and just irritating. She doesn't come even close to being the "true" cool blonde like Grace Kelly or Janet Leigh.I can see that this film would have made a huge impact in 1963, but it has NOT stood the test of time.I'm sorry, it's just stupid. I kept asking myself -- why ARE they going outside??? Go to the basement, lock yourself in a closet, get a CLUE!!!

I think The Birds is a masterpiece , but I can't explain why. Instead I'll
offer a rejoinder to anyone complaining that it isn't realistic. I have
seen that complaint registered against "Top Hat" and "The Wizard of OZ"
too.The book "Slime - How algae created us, plague us, and just might save us"
by Ruth Kassinger offers this account:
The Santa Cruz Sentinel reported that on (August 18,1961) residents
Pleasure Point and Capitola wee awakened at 3 a.m. by the clattering and
thumping of a massive flock of seabirds-sooty shearwaters, to be precise,
with three-foot wingspans - diving into the roofs of their homes. The few
people who ventured out into their yards to investigate, armed with
flashlights, saw large birds littering the streets. Many were dead, but
some only stunned, and those, attracted by the flashlights, flew at the
townspeople. In the morning, residents found the streets covered in dead
shearwaters and "bits fo fish and fish skeletons over the streets and
lawns and housetops, leaving an overpowering fishy stench." Thirty years
later, a similar event occurred, only that time it was flocks of pelicans
with the bellies full of fish - that crashed into houses in the samecoastal towns.In both instances - and no doubt other that went unrecorded - the birds
were driven mad by a toxin they'd accumulated in their bodies. The fish
they'd eaten had scarfed up zooplankton that had in turn, swallowed a
certain species of micro algae, a diatom called Pseudo-nitzschia.

Review title: Alfred Hitchcock Meets Various Species of Birds!
Review_body: After initially viewing this movie I thought to myself, how could have anyone pulled this off? Alfred Hitchcock truly is a legend that will live on in the history of cinema. He managed to grip and hold the audience as they shook in their seats much like how the birds managed to grip and hold Jessica Tandy and she shook herself to deter the birds.This epic film literally made me look out the window daring never to step outside my balcony to see if any birds were around hovering in packs ready to steer themselves into my homes.It is quite enthralling and truly spectacular to be able to capture suspense in the manner Alfred Hitchcock did in this film and actually shake the vary foundations one feels in their house, one should feel safe and secure, but after viewing this movie one will not hesitate to lock twice.Many credits should be given to anyone who participated in the making of this masterpiece and one will certainly love the beautiful Technicolor of the 1960's.The acting was magnificent and many applauds to all actors and actresses. I found the acting of Rod Taylor truly magnificent as he played the role of a man looking for love but powerfully dominated mentally by his mother while all the time having to deal with a bird infestation problem. Of course one cannot doubt the beauty of Jessica Tandy and her acting in Birds, particularly the final scene where she enters the very much realistic trance after her final attack by the birds! Overall wonderful film, and very surprised, provides a bit of many worlds which includes romance, thriller, and suspense.Thank you Hitch! (The Master of Suspense) 9/10

I believe that 'The Birds' is the worst film that I have ever seen. It had such a promising start but I'm not sure that I can fully say that the film 'ended'. The main idea being that Melanie Daniels is being attacked by birds, and then it seems to spread to the whole area and people keep getting hurt. One man is viscously murdered, which I expected to become more prominent in the film but it was just left untouched. The school children are attacked, but this is once again untouched afterwards, and the Brenner's house is attacked and that is it. No explanation, but a lot of mystery. There was not a cliff hanger to get you thinking, it ended with them driving away after being attacked. Why were the birds attacking? This is the whole plot of the film but is never explained. It had got to be Hitchcock's worst, and I am a real Hitchcock fan. Even if you love his work, this is not recommended by me at all.

Alfred Hitchcock's nightmarish tale about the avian-world inflicting a terrible vengeance on their human tormentors.Rod Taylor stars as Mitch Brenner, a bachelor lawyer. The story begins with Brenner having a fractious encounter in a San Francisco pet shop with Melanie Daniels, a chic but haughty young woman, played by Tippi Hedren, Hitchcock's latest hunk of blonde ice. Clearly smitten by the handsome attorney, the woman follows him to his home in Bodega Bay, an idyllic fishing hamlet north of the city to give him a peace offering of two love birds. However, her arrival with the captive livestock in tow seems to trigger a hostile reaction from the local feathered population. Beginning with an odd, momentary assault on the mysterious visitor by a lone seagull, all hell eventually breaks loose when thousands of marauding birds of different species repeatedly attack the small community. Jessica Tandy is Taylor's clinging and domineering mother with Veronica Cartwright as his sister and Suzanne Pleshette as his ex- girlfriend. Taylor, in his prime, looks good and makes a powerful and comforting protector in life-threatening circumstances.Although the pedestrian script by Evan Hunter (based on a short story by Daphne Du Maurier) doesn't provide any real scope for the cast, the performances are still excellent. And, in the end, Hitchcock's sheer mastery of suspense over rides any shortcomings. "The Birds" premiered in March, 1963 to somewhat mixed reviews. The public, however, showed no such ambivalence and (dare I say it ?), 'flocked' to cinemas across America to partake in the quirky horror that was on offer. Obviously, it's an effects - driven movie and on that count it still packs a punch.

Continuing with his Birds and Mothers themes carried over from his previous movie "Psycho", Hitchcock went all out for what is one of his goriest, and most disturbing films. He combined the visceral violence of "Psycho" with the large set pieces of "North by Northwest" creating a paranoid and frantic thriller, which successfully turns a mundane creature into a frightening nightmare. The Story starts, as many Hitchcock films before it, with the introduction of a young blonde woman. Although Tippi Hendren was a poor replacement for Grace Kelly, she performs adequately in the role of an initially shallow young woman. Much has been said of Hitchcock's treatment of hair during production, and Hendren herself has made some particularly libelous statements. But whatever he did, it managed to illicit of truly fearful performance during the more integral moments of the film. The Bird motif is established early on, as the first scene takes place in a Bird Shop where they're all caged and harmless, a condition which evidently changes as the film goes on. As the woman decides to pursue a man, a drama story is established, as she contends with his mother and integrates herself with his family and the town of Bodega Bay. Alongside this is the increasing intensity of Bird attacks, until eventually the focus of the story shifts to this in the final act. The slow and meticulous unraveling of the story not only allows for Hitchcock to drum up suspense, it also means that when the characters are under the most extreme threat we have spent a lot of time with them, and know them inside and out. This means that we feel every hit that they take, as well as making us more fearful for them. The choice of Hitchcock to not use a traditional soundtrack, despite having Bernard Herman at his disposal, was an inspired one. The cawing of the Birds is a grating and piercing noise, and is more relevant to the content of the film than a traditional horror score. The film looks beautiful, the camera captures the picturesque nature of the setting perfectly,and it is filled with strong primary colours. These 2 things make it a major departure from "Psycho" and shows what a pioneering and innovative director Hitchcock was, always looking to change and challenge himself, while still employing his tried and tested techniques of drumming up tension and suspense. This is an excellent thriller, and you'll likely never look at Birds the same way again.

i only watched this film because i had heard so much about it and it was being shown on ITV new years day. I found the film to be good for the time it was made, and it had an interesting story... but i haven't been able to stop thinking about it since i watched it! the birds just cant attack for no reason, so i came up with the following conclusions: 1) in the bird shop at the beginning, mitch says to Melanie that the birds shouldn't be kept in captivity.. (i cant remember the exact words) but it made me think about whether the birds were attacking because they didn't like the lovebirds being in the cage, and as they were all different species of birds attacking, i thought whether they were sticking together and therefore making the people in the film feel like they are in captivity themselves. 2) the birds only seem to attack when there is fire/smoke. when Melanie is at the school, she lights a cigarette, the birds come. when the lady in the café towards the end is playing with the match to light her cigarette, the birds appear, and in the final bit in the house, the light a fire and Melanie gets attacked. i am sure i will think of more, but please do post and tell me what you think of my theories!

Not only is this a great film (Hitchcock's best), but what a great example of the kind of repercussions that await us if man doesn't stop waging war on the environment. How much is Mother Earth supposed to take before she decides it's time to fight back. When it comes down to Man vs. Nature, Nature always wins! In the film, the lovebirds are caged rather than free to live in nature, and Zeke, the fishing boat captain, tells of how his crew had to drive off the birds trying to eat the fish they caught (as man again tries to keep the bounty of nature all to himself). We should all come away from this film both wiser and more sympathetic to the wanton destruction we have unjustifiably perpetrated on our environment.

I very much understand the technical importance of this film regarding the difficulty and incision of Hitchcock's magic but I also think this ranks among his most overrated films. In no way do I deny that Hitchcock is among the greatest film directors that ever lived, but I think that this film is relatively weak, perhaps among the same lower class as the likes of, for instance, The Man Who Knew Too much (remake, of course!!)For me, Rebecca is a Du Maurier masterclass by the Hitch, very much up there amongst his best (my personal fave!) but is this not merely a waste of Hitchcock's subtlety, directing a modern equivalent of, say, Independence day?!

Review title: One of the Most Overrated Movies of All Time
Review_body: I know this movie is often described as a "masterpiece" and for the life of me, I don't understand why.First of all: the acting is completely wooden from virtually everyone in the movie. It could be that the actors could find no motivation for their characters. Whatever is supposed to be happening or building between the characters in the first half of the movie seems to lead to absolutely nothing int he movie. It's vague back story for the sake of back story. If Hitchcock was trying to have us care about the characters, he failed miserably. Second, and perhaps most important: what do the birds have to do with any of this vapid soap opera that is occurring on the ground? Nothing. Nothing at all. And that would be fine, if somehow the bird frenzy created some sort of empathy in the viewer or brought about a change or revelation in the characters. But no, I found myself not caring if the whole town got eked to death. The characters all come across as shallow, self-centered, bitter people.I know I might get the wrath of many fans of this movie. But, sorry, this movie fails on so many levels.

Everyone can say what they want, i believe this is a great movie.

The Birds, directed by Alfred Hitchcock, is a really strange movie. It has a complicated plot which can sometimes drive you crazy. However, the storyline is quite interesting and original, for the time. It takes a while to get into the story, it would be better if the issue that the characters have to face came earlier, because it is really long, and boring. The acting sometimes was a bit overacted. The main actress, Tippi Hedren, is really pretty and plays well, and Rod Taylor is also a good actor. The mother's character, played by Jessica Tandy, can seem annoying because she is overprotective with her son, not being nice to whoever he brings home. The movie fits the society of that time, like the fact that there is no father in the family, or their way of life which is normal. The special effects can seem ridiculous, but for 1963 it has an amazing quality. It was realistic at that time. However, the end is realistic but the suspense goes on and on, and it doesn't have a real end. It seems like the movie was just cut off because there isn't an outcome. The suspense is good and you want to discover more, but since there's no ending, you don't know the end of the story and it's frustrating.

The major problem is that there is no real end, so we don't really no why birds attacked. It is a great film but there is no point in watching it because its main issue isn't solved at the end, Hitchcock lets us with no answer, it is so disappointing. Even if the film ends too early as if it was cut, the plot is really original and passionate. The actors are well chosen, Mitch (Rod Taylor) is the man for the job. Althrough the film we can feel a tense atmosphere, particularly when Melanie (Tippi Hedren) climbs the stairs to look into the bedroom. The story is very absorbing, but the movie is too short ! Hitchcock is really the master of suspense ! He was very talented for his time ! A movie to see if you love no end movies.

This movie was great and enjoyable,because the movie maker, Hithcock himself, produces an amazing suspense which will amaze you. The plot is based on a pathetic love story which involves Mitch and Melanie. Some stereotypes are very visible for instance : Melanie is weak, and Mitch is a kind of hero in this movie, he is indeed The Husband. However, an attack of birds is creative and original compared to the other typical horror movies, which is a good point. The story is a bit boring, and it ends up going nowhere, especiallly considering that the end is very disappointing.We advise you to Watch this movie if you enjoy suspense and old-fashionned movies!

Review title: Please take the time to read this is you are considering watching this film!
Review_body: I first encountered this film back when it was released and couldn't watch all of it as it was so horrific! I fell like the horror genre is one of my favourites and i have sat through some of the scariest of films out there so don't take me for an old scardycat! However even now in this day and age I found myself almost vomiting with terror whilst that young lady is attacked in the phone booth! The scene where youths are attacked from the sky is quite possibly one of the most horrific, graphic and nerve shredding scenes you will ever encounter in film history! Film directors nowadays use all this fancy computer stuff but Hitchcock hit the nail on the head with the visual effects in this film! It looks so real that Betty from next door thought it was an actual report on the TV! Quite a shock she had I can tell you now. Well i shall keep this brief i don't want to appear to be banging on but I end with a warning. Do not watch this film alone especially not with children present! It is highly disturbing and I have not been able to leave my own residence for a week now. Quite frankly the worst thing youl ever watch its unbearable!

Review title: Not Hitchcock's finest, but overall a great film
Review_body: The Birds, Alfred Hitchcock's second adaptation of a Daphne du Maurier novel (the first being Rebecca), is about a fictional town in Northern California which is attacked by birds after Melanie Daniels, the main character, comes to visit a man who caught her interest, Mitch Brenner. It is a thriller/horror.Overall, the film was well-done. Although not as great as some of Hitchcock's other films, he definitely left his mark on it, as he does with all of his films: the dark humor, the haunting mom character, and, of course, the blonde female victim.Using key collaborators which have worked with him on other projects, Hitchcock used his skilled team to make a great film. Robert Burks, the cinematographer who worked with Hitchcock on other projects such as Strangers on a Train (1951), Dial M for Murder (1954), Rear Window (1954), To Catch a Thief (1955), Vertigo (1958), and North by Northwest (1959) did a remarkable job. This one shot, where he shoots upwards, after the last attack, is terrifying as I kept expecting another one.What I found in Hitchcock's films, specifically in this one, is that the action scenes aren't the scary part, the anticipation to them is. The scene in which Melanie goes up the stairs and you just know something bad is going to happen and there will be birds was more nerve-wrecking than the actual attack. This, in my opinion, is Hitchcock's strong point. He is able to hold the suspense in such a way that is shuddersome.Regarding the comedy, in the scene in the diner, the one guy who kept commenting on it being the end of the world was fitting for Hitchcock's humor, as it was more comedic than actually serious.Although there was no musical score in the film, Bernard Hermann is still credited as a sound consultant. I found that fact interesting, as there wasn't even a beginning score, just the sound of birds.The female character was, of course, the victim once again in this film as in many others of Hitchcock. Male superiority is clearly seen. An example in this film is when the man at the gas station is hit. Mitch orders Melanie to stay inside while the rest of the "hopeless" females and children watch on the sidelines as the brave men go outside to try and save the day.As said earlier, the film was overall a good one. It is too overrated when it comes down to it being as scary as people say. The performances were good, nothing great or exceptional such as in Hitchcock's Rear Window. Hitchcock used his "suspense-skill" in a perfect way and his sense of humor shone through as well .

Review title: Take the time to unravel the meaning of this masterpiece.
Review_body: This movie seems to be so misunderstood by so many. Many don't understand it. Many that praise it need to also watch it again to have more to praise than suspense and special effects.Begin with the characters.Mitch Brenner is a unmarried successful San Francisco lawyer. I will cue you in here... today he would be able to legally marry his male partner. His double life is spent during the week in SF and weekends being a good son in Bodega Bay.Lydia Brenner is Mitch's mother. Seemingly insecure since her husband died and left her with 2 children. Seemingly insecure, but really the domineering and overprotective mother shielding her boy from women like Melanie Daniels and Anne Heyward. Going as far as criticizing him for not being as smart and in control of it all, as his father. Chopping him down to a little boy, because his father would have known how to protect the family.Anne Heyward the school teacher. Deep voiced and sexy. Ex-lover of Mitch that moved to Bodega Bay just to be near Mitch She reveals their relationship never got off the ground because of his mother as well as other reasons. One line of dialogue to Melanie was, "I don't think there has ever been anything between Mitch and any woman". She indicates that when she was no longer a threat to Lydia and her control over Mitch, Lydia and she became close friend and Mitch and her became like brother and sister.Melanie Daniels. Wealthy, beautiful, chic, educated, fun party girl, world traveler, well groomed to 1962 perfection. Well guess who really never has a truly romantic moment with this cool, sophisticated, wealthy, party girl, blonde beauty? In the pet store scene one would expect any hunk of a healthy red blooded heterosexual male to be at least flirting with her, not intentionally making a fool out of her. I think his overall lack of interest in doing anything other than playing this unfriendly game reeks of a sarcastic distrust of woman... but he probably trusts his mother. Miss Grundy. A local Bodega Bay ornithologist that is the only one that thinks all the incidents of bird attacks are ridiculous exaggeration. Grundy wears man tailored clothing. Her hairstyle, outfit, and demeanor is more of a masculine dignified Englishman than a Northern Californian elderly woman. She even smokes a pipe with butch gestures. HOLD ON TO YOUR HATS EVERYONE... HERE COME THE BIRDS!!!! Explanation of the Birds... Mitch has now a second beautiful woman following and showing heavy interest in being with him. How many will he reject? How long can he hide, showing ambivalent feelings towards women as they arrive one after the other. Rivaling each other in attractiveness. How long before the towns people start calling him, Lydia's weird son that never married? The birds represent Mitch's homosexuality. They attack women and children mostly. First Melanie. Then the gull smashes Anne's door where those two women are just relaxing. Anne says, Poor thing must have got confused and flew into the light". The children's birthday party. In the house after dinner through the fire place. Only one single male farmer was attacked in a detailed scene. He could be someone one else that may have known about Mitch. The school children. The decent on the whole town. Anne's death. Melanie, Lydia, and Anne certainly had more than a real good hint about Mitch. You can't hide it anymore Mitch. It's come home to roost! So Melanie hears some rustling upstairs while the others sleep. Melanie should know what that means. She has to have figured out by now where Mitch is concerned, something is wrong in the bedroom. Obviously his bedroom has not seen much action with women. She opens the door and is attacked and nearly killed by the birds... they peck at her and make shrieking, and scowling noises. Rescued by Mitch and Lydia she is in a state of shock. One gets the feeling as they drive away that they may never return to Bodega Bay. Lydia holds Melanie in the back seat of the car reminiscent of the Blessed Mother cradling Jesus in Michael Amgelo's statue, The Pieta. Could you ever imagine Mitch and Melanie ever being in a relationship ever again? Seems like Mitch has turned another woman into a sister.

Review title: A Powerful Punch of Suspense, a Light Tap of Everything Else
Review_body: Alfred Hitchcock is arguably one of the most genre-defining directors of cinema history. With such classics like "Psycho," "Rear Window," "Vertigo," etc., there's a clear, undeniable reason he is considered Hollywood's "Master of Suspense."I will agree with the common thought that he is one of the top directors of our time; however, his 1963 film, "The Birds," is not something I would personally accept as being one of his better productions.I do have a rather negative opinion of this movie, though truthfully, I've seen MUCH worse. There's simply a lot I don't like about the plot, the characters, and the film's approach to the conflict at-hand. Without going into too much detail (or major spoilers), I truly believed this movie could've been done a lot better. Okay, so the suspense aspect was TERRIFIC; that's the one and only thing I'll give this movie and A+ for, as the whole "bird" concept was (mostly) executed with perfection. To today's standards, the special effects were cheesy (keeping in mind this film is nearing 60 years old), but I couldn't help myself but feeling terrified going into the final act of the movie. Basically, the last thirty minutes of this two- hour film was fantastic. I was on-edge, scared, and downright frightened by the way the conflict influenced character development.That said, that was the only thing I liked about the movie.I felt like the first act of the movie was weak, boring, and almost pointless. The purpose of the first hour was to introduce the characters, develop the conflict, and try to create chemistry between each member of the cast. None of these things, however, were ever fulfilled enough for me. The movie spent so much time on the characters that I ending up barely caring about the bird conflict when it became prevalent. I don't mind slow movies at all - in fact, the slowness in a movie is supposed to make thrillers more suspenseful - but the amount of time focused on the protagonist and her motives became ridiculously overbearing. The worst thing is, NONE of this wrapped up in the end. All of the time spend on Melanie's love affairs never amounted to anything, and barely made sense when romanticizing (in its brevity) actually occurred. Simply put, character chemistry was barely sub-par.But characters aren't always the most important thing, right? In a Hitchcock film, it's all about the ending and the suspenseful events that led up to it. Sure, I'll agree with that, but I can't help but notice the numerous plot holes the movie had, the unanswered questions the film created, and the brutally disappointing ending - completely left up to the viewer's interpretation. Why were the birds there? What made them so aggressive? What was the point of the love birds? Did they ever make it out of their driveway? Honestly, things just didn't make sense with this one. The film gives us ideas to think about and toy with, but not enough direction throughout the production to make a reasonable inference.

Having just screened the movie I feel the need to warn future viewers that it is 2:21:54 long not 120 minutes! I see the movie listed everywhere citing 119 or 120 minutes but I just ran it... 2:22 from the trolley car to the end credit.My audience was my wife and 20 y.o. son neither of which had ever seen it. Both were appropriately uneasy during the movie and both felt unsettled when it was over. Score: Hitchcock 1, Time 0

Fist off, I love the movie, Hitch was a true master. I do have a question about the film, however. Tippi Hedren is seen driving a really sweet sports car throughout the course of the movie. Now, I THINK it's an Aston Martin but there just aren't enough good clear shots of the car for me to be certain - so I am not sure. I've been debating this with some friends in the office - one thinks it is an Alvis (but if it were an Alvis it'd be quite a bit larger, in my opinion) - however - I'm sure someone out in movie-trivia land knows what the exact make and model designation are. If you happen to know I'd appreciate the information - so - holler back at me at stevehconsult@yahoo.com with the answer! Thanks Steve

This movie is definitely gripping in parts but why on Earth do the birds attack only at certain times? This is never really revealed. The development of the characters is also wafer thin. Having said that, this is a genuine Hitchcock thriller. It came during the peak of the great masters powers films like Rear Window,Vertigo, North by Northwest, Psycho, and the Birds all appearing within a ten year period. Hitchcock's earlier and later films with the possible exception of Frenzy in 1972 never quite seemed as captivating as what Hitchcock produced in the 50s and early 60s. It featured the debut of the masculine Australian actor Rod Steiger who went on to become a widely respected actor. Hitchcock's fascination with blondes continues with Tippi Hedren in this case being the leading lady. The location of Bodega Bay, California seems ideal and portrays the intended isolation quite nicely. A little more meaningful dialogue and character development would have been all that this needed to become a true and timeless classic. Well worth a watch.

Intense buildup of suspense. A true challenge before the age of computers, special effects, and dumbed-down scripts. How they trained all those birds alone is amazing. The master's finest achievement. Visually beautiful, despite so many unforgettable, frightening images. Ed McBain, the screenwriter, gave this interview (http://www.mysterynet.com/hitchcock/mcbain.shtml) explaining his original ending. Robin Wood wrote a profound analysis in his book, Hitchcock's Films, for anyone wishing to study the movie. I think it's great that The Birds is still shown to school kids as an example of polished artwork.

Review title: I will never get tired of this movie
Review_body: I remember watching this movie when I was just a small child, and noticing that a lot of things were familiar to me. I find myself looking at the background of the movie all the time, trying to pick out new details and locations every time. This movie used a number of locations that were very familiar to me as I grew up going to Bodega and Bodega Bay almost every weekend, and had relatives in Sebastopol and Santa Rosa. My uncle's gate was used for the scene where the kids run from the school down to the Tides. So many locations are familiar to me that I feel like I am going back in time every time I watch it. I love this movie, and will never tire from watching it. Hitchcock does it like nobody ever will again.
It builds up a mystery but never even solves it, why are the birds attacking people? We don't know, and no one ever finds out apparently.
